articles.title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS:
articles.summary: This article provides a comprehensive calendar of events for the San Jose Amateur Astronomers during May and early June. It details various club activities, including general meetings featuring guest speakers, board meetings, field expeditions for astronomical observation, and in-valley star parties. Notable events include a vote on changing the club's name, the annual board member elections, a spring slide exposition, and participation in the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference.

articles.title: PAST EVENTS
articles.summary: The article reports on several astronomy events held in April, including two 'Astronomy Day' public viewing sessions, one at K-Mart with low turnout and another at the Rosicrucian Museum during a partial lunar eclipse that attracted about 500 people. A successful star party at Fremont Peak State Park featured John Dobson's 24-inch telescope and a rare observation of Pluto, while another star party at Skyline was hampered by poor sky conditions.

articles.title: News Flash!
articles.summary: The State Park District is converting the long-used Skyline observing site into a roadside park, making it unusable for club members. The area previously used for telescopes and cars has been dug up for picnic tables, and a new paved parking lot will be unsuitable due to heavy traffic on Highway 9. This change eliminates a cherished and long-standing observing location for the club.

articles.title: Bay Area Planetarium Guide
articles.summary: This document is a comprehensive guide to Bay Area planetarium programs and schedules for Spring 1977. It lists numerous planetariums across East Bay, South Bay, Peninsula, and San Francisco, detailing their operating hours, specific program titles, dates of operation, and admission costs. The guide also provides contact information, notes on reservations, and age restrictions for attendees.

articles.title: KEY
articles.summary: The document lists key entities related to astronomy and education, specifically highlighting 'Educational Institutions', the 'Stanford Radio Telescope', 'Planetariums', and 'Observatories'. It appears to be a quick reference or index of significant locations and types of organizations in these fields.

articles.title: LOS MEDANOS COLLEGE
articles.summary: This document provides location information for various California cities, features an address and showroom hours for an Oakland establishment, and prominently mentions LOS MEDANOS COLLEGE. It also highlights the OPTICA b/c COMPANY, a member of the Pacific Planetarium Association, emphasizing its central location among numerous observatories, planetaria, space research centers, and astronomy education institutions.

articles.title: Membership Renewals
articles.summary: Members of the San Jose Amateur Astronomers should anticipate receiving their yellow Sky and Telescope renewal cards shortly. Regular membership costs $15, while junior membership (under 18) is $10. Payments should be made to Treasurer John Rhodes, with checks payable to "San Jose Amateur Astronomers."

articles.title: News Notz
articles.summary: This article, titled "News Notz," provides several brief updates in astronomy, including recent findings on meteorite origins, new evidence for supernova-triggered star birth, and details on Nova Sagittarii 1977's discovery and brightening. It also reports on the redesigned Space Telescope's specifications and anticipated 1983 launch. Additionally, the document includes specific directions and access instructions for a location near Anderson Reservoir and Henry Coe Park.

articles.title: Rattley Rattles
articles.summary: An astronomical organization is awaiting approval from the University of Santa Clara to use its observatory and its 16-inch Alvan Clark refractor, with prospects looking favorable for use within six months. The society plans to utilize the observatory for meetings, public education, and various astronomical projects like astrophotography and variable star observations, also proposing telescope restoration and modifications. The university's primary condition is non-personal use, and the article also briefly announces an upcoming special meeting for a constitutional vote.

articles.title: SJAA
articles.summary: The San Jose Amateur Astronomers (SJAA) is proposing to change its name to the San Jose Astronomical Association to cultivate a more professional image, with a membership vote pending. The document also provides comprehensive details for the 9th annual Riverside Telescope Makers Conference, scheduled for May 21-22, 1977, at Camp Oakes, including accommodation options, costs, and reservation instructions.

articles.title: LUNAR OCCULTATIONS
articles.summary: This article provides a detailed schedule of lunar occultation events occurring from late April through early June, including specific dates, times, and observational parameters like star magnitude, lunar illumination, elevation, cusp angle, and position angle. It offers observational advice for prominent events like ZC0944 and defines the technical headings used in the event table for astronomers and observers.

articles.title: SATURN
articles.summary: This document provides updates and explanations regarding tables and figures for Saturn and its moons, noting variations due to a constant scale and a slightly smaller scaled figure for Saturn this month. The author discusses the challenges of observing satellites close to the planet, offers guidance on scope sizes, and invites readers to share their observational findings to refine the data.

articles.title: Moons and Stars Observation Data
articles.summary: This document presents detailed observation data for several moons, primarily focusing on Saturn's major satellites. It includes a table with astronomical characteristics such as visual magnitude, recommended telescope aperture, and orbital period for eight moons. Following this, the document provides daily positional observation logs for these moons over several weeks in May and early June.
